Brief Hospital Course:
This is an ___ year old female with past medical history of 
atrial fibrillation recently started on apixaban and metoprolol, 
admitted ___ with acute diastolic CHF, palpitations in 
setting of poorly controlled heart rates, status post diuresis 
and augmented rate control able to be discharged to assisted 
living

==================== 
ACUTE/ACTIVE ISSUES:  
====================
  
# Acute diastolic CHF 
# Acute hypoxic respiratory failure
# Persistent atrial fibrillation
Presented with increasing dyspnea on exertion, subacute fatigue, 
and worsening lower extremity edema. Examination notable for 
bibasilar crackles. Labs were notable for normal WBC and mildly 
elevated NT-proBNP ___. CXR without small right pleural 
effusion.  EKG and telemetry notable for afib with poorly 
controlled ventricular rates.  No signs infection, dehydration 
or other secondary driver of afib.  Concern was for poorly 
controlled atrial fibrillation leading to acute diastolic CHF 
due to increased heart rates.  Patient was diuresed with bolus 
doses of IV furosemide with improvement in symptoms and 
resolution of hypoxia. Cardiology were consulted for 
consideration of TEE/DCCV due to concern she might not be 
tolerating atrial fibrillation from heart failure perspective.  
TEE demonstrated spontaneous echo contrast in the left atrium, 
and DCCV had to be aborted.  Unclear if this was 
secondary to missed dose of apixaban on day prior to admission, 
or patient being on the dose-reduced dosing of apixaban.  Per 
discussion with cardiology, increased apixaban to 5mg BID.  
Metoprolol was up-titrated to achieve better rate and symptom 
control. Patient achieved euvolemia, thought to be 132lbs.  Due 
to concern that as her heart rate improved her diuretic need 
would decrease (see hyponatremia below) risk/benefit was felt to 
favor discharge on PO furosemide 20mg every other day to start 
on ___.  Scheduled patient follow-up with PCP ___ ___ 
for weight check and Chem-10 check to ensure diuretic regimen is 
appropriate. Decision if/when to proceed with repeat TEE/DCCV is 
deferred to outpatient cardiologist.

# Hyponatremia
Course notable for mild hyponatremia.  ___ have initially 
represented hypervolemic, but then worsened--to 132 as she 
continued to be diuresed.  Suspect the latter component related 
to diuresis below dry weight (hypovolemic).  Sodium improved to 
135 with changing to every other day diuretic regimen.  
Follow-up as above. 
 
# GERD
Continued omeprazole 20mg BID. 

# Hypothyroidism
Continued levothyroxine 88mcg daily.

# Hyperlipidemia 
Patient no longer taking pravastatin as an outpatient.

# Open angle glaucoma 
Continued dorzolamide 2%/timolol 0.5% Ophth left eye BID.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

WHY DID YOU COME TO THE HOSPITAL?
You were admitted to the hospital as you were having shortness 
of breath and worsening leg swelling

WHAT HAPPENED WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL?
- You were given IV medication to remove the extra fluid from 
your body
- You underwent an echocardiogram which showed a clot in your 
heart; as such we did not attempt cardioversion
- We increased your medication to slow your heart rate to help 
control your palpitations
- You were transitioned to an oral diuretic to prevent fluid 
from building back up again

WHAT YOU NEED TO DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?
- Please follow-up with all of your outpatient providers as 
advised
- It is important you take all of your medications as prescribed

It was a pleasure taking care of you!
